reviews.author: Brian.ust
reviews.title: A course with traditional Chinese and Western culture
reviews.comment_content: Lectures cover wide range of Chinese and Western culture and values including Utilitarianism, Kantianism, Mohism, Confucianism, Daoism, destiny and well-beings. Majority of the topics will be tested on quizzes and only one concept out of Utilitarianism, Kantianism, Mohism, Confucianism is required to appear in your essay and you can find some useful points on Dr Nam's recommended readings.
reviews.comment_teaching: Dr Nam managed to deliver his powerpoint slides with some real-life examples which helps me understand some difficult terms and theories. However, his English has a large room for improvement which you need extra attention on his class since some questions in the quiz will be disclosed on lectures. Dr Susanna Ho and Dr Nam both spent extra time for consultation on the 1000-word essay, which one should realize what they ask for and how one can improve from the draft essay. The teaching on lectures was a bit not understandable but both quizzes only test your memory of the exact wordings in the ppt. However, the teaching on the tutorial is essential for you to write the essay smoothly and attendance and some little practices on Canvas are required.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is not really transparent. Only scores of the two quizzes will be disclosed while both the score for canvas discussion and essay will not be disclosed. But one obvious thing is that the essay must be the dominating part towards your grade.

Score:
Quiz 1: 17/20 (Mean: 13.7)
Quiz 2: 15/20 (Mean: 14.7)

Turn out A
reviews.comment_workload:
Not Heavy. One two-hour class per week on theories by Dr Nam and one 50-minute tutorial class every two weeks by Dr Susanna Ho.
Percentage Allocation:
Canvas Discussion, two topics for each discussion, two discussions in total (10%)
Two Quizzes (Each 10%= 20%)
1000-word essay (50%)
Attendance for tutorials (10%)
Little Practice on Canvas for tutorial (10%)

reviews.author: Doug Stamper
reviews.title: Weird
reviews.comment_content:
Mentioned above.
Generally speaking, if you are interested in it, it will be interesting.
The only sad thing about this course is, it doesn't seem encouraging to me in pursuing further. Guess that's a shame for humanity course
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor doesn't excel in English nor Mandarin. And this course presents itself in only 2 ways: English and Mandarin. This is proven problematic because effective communication is of the essence in disciplines not that rigorous, such as humanity.
The topics are fun but the teaching doesn't make one wanna go further.
If you are the person that come and go while expecting good grades, I don't think the content is well-designed for quizzes since professor's lectures center on answering studs' questions. And those questions usually can't help quizzes. I personally attended 90% of lectures and still averaged in quizzes. The reason is because knowing more doesn't nail quizzes. Quizzes require "exact wordings" copied from powerpoints, which is counter-intuitive most of the time.
If you are interested in this subject in the first place, the lecture helps. Yet, I argue it is limited. The lecture material centers on one and only one thing--answering questions. However, no extra material such as extra readings offered in Canvas are discussed. This is disappointing since the inherent nature of this course is simplicity. It isn't that hard for one to comprehend the content beforehand. Guess I am expecting too much from the lecture.

Now, since 50% of this course is devoted to essay. There are 4 writing workshops.
These workshops are nothing but deplorable.
5 minutes consultation session on average per person. This is far from enough. The tutor do not come prepared in general. Yes, the workload for a 1-to-40 workshop is understandable. But you can extend it. Or do whatever you can. I simply can't see why is efficiency built at the expense on students.
reviews.comment_grading:
Got 10 marks above the mean in course overall score.
Scored A- at the end.
Not bad.
reviews.comment_workload:
Weekly quizzes are bizarre. You can complete quizzes on spot--even watching the lecture videos are optional since the quiz has no time limit and above all, investing time, for example, reading extra material, asking questions, may not nail the quizzes. Again, it's about exam skills. And nothing in this course trains this bit. So, you can literally do nothing and still do extremely good or bad.
The essay is, again, simple.
Let's save the trouble. Everything is simple. Just follow their schedule. Then you can enjoy your life.

reviews.author: penguin3220
reviews.title: 一個幾好grade嘅HUMA Course
reviews.comment_content:
Module 1 - Introduction
Module 2a - Moral Conflict in Western Ethics I: Utility in Utilitarianism
Module 2b - Moral Conflict in Western Ethics II: Categorical Imperative in Kantianism
Module 2c - Moral Conflict in Chinese Philosophy I: Uprightness in Confucianism
Module 2d - Moral Conflict in Chinese Philosophy II: Inclusive Care in Mohism
Module 3 - Dissolving the Moral Conflict: Rationale of Dissolving Moral Conflict in the Thought of Daoism
Module 4a - Destiny I: The Concept of Tian (天) and Ming (命)
Module 4b - Destiny II: The Distinction between Righteousness and Destiny in the Thought of Mencius
Module 5a - Well-being I: Self-establishment and Detachment of Zhuangzi

望落好似幾難，但其實讀落都ok
reviews.comment_teaching: The lessons are quite boring, but Dr. Nam is one of the best professors I've ever met. Although he may not good at teaching big classes, you can ask him questions after class and he is willing to answer them explicitly. He also provides some extra lessons in Cantonese for some difficult topics so I could understand the content very well.
reviews.comment_grading:
ONLINE DISCUSSION 10%
There are 3 discussions to do. It is quite time consuming and seems not worthy enough to spend that much time for just 10%. However, it does has a large effect on your final grade. (could be 2 sub-grades more or less)

WRITING WORKSHOP (ONLINE + CLASSROOM) 20%
Everyone can get full marks once you finish all online quizzes (unlimited trials) and attend all tutorial lessons (隔個禮拜一次)

ESSAY 50%
Spend more time on the essay, you can consult the professor before the essay submission. (He would provide some time slots for you to register)

QUIZZES 20%
2 MC quizzes (not cumulative): each quiz has 16 questions, you can get 20% if you answer 27 questions correctly out of 32. The quizzes are not difficult, most of the students could get >18% in the end.

MY GRADE
Online Discussion: 6-7/10
Workshop: Full marks
Essay: 43.7/50
Quizzes: Full marks (Mean 18.15, S.D. 2.75)
Overall: >90/100
Grade: A-
reviews.comment_workload:
Things you have to do:
- Essay (1000 words)
- 3 Online Discussions
- Online Quizzes
- Tutorial Lessons

reviews.comment_workload:
Having three canvas online discussions. It seems the workloads will be light. However, when every students are too serious and diligent to pursue good grade. One final essay is needed, writing about 1000 words. There are various topics you could choose to write.

reviews.author: hypetrain
reviews.title: Great course
reviews.comment_content:
“At fifteen, I had my mind bent on learning. At thirty, I stood firm. At forty, I had no doubts. At fifty, I knew the Tianming (天命). At sixty, my ear was an obedient organ for the reception of truth. At seventy, I could follow what my heart desired, without transgressing what was right.” This is a self-reflection of Confucius. The improvement throughout his life, not only demonstrates the life of a man of virtue (junzi 君子), but also highlights the dialectical characteristic of Chinese philosophy. This characteristic can be shown by the correlation between righteousness, destiny and well-being.

Lectures and readings will be (mainly) built upon selected texts of Chinese classics. Through studying the texts, students will reflect and explore the deep meanings and relationship between the concepts of righteousness, destiny and well-being, which demonstrate the dialectical characteristic of philosophy of life in both Classical Confucianism and Classical Daoism. For the concept of righteousness, moral conflict between Confucianism and Mohism will be explored, together with the idea of dissolving the distinction between right and wrong in Daoism. For the concept of destiny, the discussion will begin with the ideas of endeavor (li 力) and destiny (ming 命) in the Liezi, followed by possible replies from Mencius, Xunzi and Zhuangzi. As for the concept of well-being, the ultimate goals of the philosophy of life in Confucianism and Daoism will be discussed, and the possibility of obtaining well-being under the influence of destiny will be shown.

Course highlights:

3-credit HUMA common core course with no exam but one essay, Canvas online peer discussion, and two quizzes.
Learn how to convince others in writing.
Learn more about three specific values: “Righteousness”, “Destiny” and “Well-being”.
